spanishExample: ¡Buen día! ¿Todo bien? ¿Ya te vas?
englishTranslation: Good day! All good? Are you leaving already?
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: ¡Buenas noches! ¿Cuánto han *paid* por estar aquí?
englishTranslation: Good evening! How much have they paid because of being here?
vocabIncluded: cuánto: adverb meaning "how much?" in a question or implied question
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: ¡Buenos días! ¡Usted tiene *a big smile today!*
englishTranslation: Good morning! You(formal) have a big smile today!
vocabIncluded: usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: ¡De nada! ¿Cómo tienen esas cosas?
englishTranslation: You’re welcome! How do they have those things?
vocabIncluded: cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¡Gracias! ¿Y dónde nos *can we feed?*
englishTranslation: Thank you! And where can we feed ourselves?
vocabIncluded: dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¡Hola! Me voy a *introduce.*
englishTranslation: Hi! I’m going to introduce myself!
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¡Ya está! Me puedo ir ya que no voy a tener más.
englishTranslation: All done! I can leave since I’m not going to have more.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
ya está: idiom meaning "it's done", "all done", etc.
ya que: idiom meaning "since" in a logical sense

spanishExample: Buenas tardes, señor, tengo sus *keys*por si las *you need.*
englishTranslation: Good afternoon, sir, I have your(formal) keys in case you need them(f).
vocabIncluded: las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things

spanishExample: Él ha estado ahí, pero ellos no han estado.
englishTranslation: He has been there, but they haven’t been present.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: En verdad, has tenido *problems* con la señorita.
englishTranslation: Actually, you have had problems with the young lady.
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Ese hombre es tan *tall* que no he *seen* alguien como él.
englishTranslation: That man is so tall that I haven’t seen someone like him.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)
tan: "so" as an adverb right before an adjective or adverb

spanishExample: Esta noche hay *a lot of food.*
englishTranslation: This night there is a lot of food.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: Habrá las *same* cosas que ya había.
englishTranslation: There will be the same things that there already were.
vocabIncluded: habrá: "there will be" indicating existence (Haber, future, impersonal)
había: "there was/were" indicating existence (Haber, imperfect, impersonal)
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Hemos tenido lo que la mujer tiene.
englishTranslation: We have had what the woman has.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: La verdad es que ella está por tener una *new* casa.
englishTranslation: The truth is that she is about to have a new house.
vocabIncluded: the use of "por" after Estar to mean "about to"

spanishExample: Lo bueno es que la señora ha tenido una buena vida.
englishTranslation: The good(thing) is that the lady has had a good life.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No tenemos esas cosas este año.
englishTranslation: We don’t have those things this year.

spanishExample: Nunca he hecho algo así.
englishTranslation: I have never done something like that.
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Se va, como *she wants* hacer.
englishTranslation: She is leaving, as she wants to do.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Solo tengo una casa.
englishTranslation: I only have a house.

spanishExample: Tenemos *a party* esta tarde y ellos tienen *a concert.*
englishTranslation: We have a party this afternoon and they have a concert.

spanishExample: Tienes *a lot of work* por tu *boss.*
englishTranslation: You have a lot of work because of your boss.

spanishExample: Tienes *money* al haber *worked.*
englishTranslation: You have money upon having worked.
vocabIncluded: haber: "to have", "having" before a participle (Haber, infinitive)
